titles.title: To condemn the release by the Government of Malta of convicted terrorist Mohammed Ali Rezaq.

action.text: Referred to the House Committee on Foreign Affairs.
Referred to the Subcommittee on Europe and the Middle East.
Referred to the Subcommittee on International Security, International Organizations and Human Rights.

committee.name: House Committee on Foreign Affairs
committee.subcommittee: International Security, International Organizations and Human Rights

action.text: Subcommittee Consideration and Mark-up Session Held.

committee.name: House Committee on Foreign Affairs
committee.subcommittee: International Security, International Organizations and Human Rights

calendar.text: Ordered to be Reported (Amended) in the Nature of a Substitute.

action.text: Committee Consideration and Mark-up Session Held.

calendar.text: Ordered to be Reported by Voice Vote.

action.text: Subcommittee on Europe and the Middle East Discharged.
Mr. Lantos moved to suspend the rules and agree to the resolution, as amended.
Considered under suspension of the rules.
DEBATE - The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate.

At the conclusion of debate, the Yeas and Nays were demanded and ordered. Pursuant to the provisions of clause 5, rule I, the chair announced that further proceedings on the motion would be postponed until March 30.

vote.text: On motion to suspend the rules and agree to the resolution, as amended Agreed to by the Yeas and Nays: (2/3 required): 421 - 0 (Roll no. 119).

action.text: Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.

committee.name: House Foreign Affairs
committee.subcommittee: International Security, International Organizations, and Human Rights

bill.summary: 3/30/1993--Passed House amended. Condemns the release by the Government of Malta of convicted terrorist Mohammed Ali Rezaq. Urges all governments to: (1) cooperate in transferring Rezaq to the United States or to another concerned country to face criminal charges for involvement in the Egypt Air hijacking of November 1985 and the murder of civilians; and (2) not provide safe haven to terrorists. Urges the President to review the U.S. relationship with Malta.
